awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Dynamic Invasive Species Control Optimization Via Integrated Education and Research (DISCOVER)
awd_abstract_narration:
1554018 (Buyuktahtakin). The goal of this research is to design optimal intervention and resource allocation strategies to protect ecological systems from the detrimental impacts of invasive species. This research goal will be pursued through four specific objectives: (1) designing a novel mathematical optimization framework; (2) investigating a new class of game theoretic problems to coordinate multiple stakeholders (e.g., government, land managers, cooperatives) in invasive species management and provide insight into public policy decisions; (3) formulating and solving novel surveillance and control problems under uncertainty; and (4) performing experiments to demonstrate the potential benefit of the proposed models and algorithms by using real-life cases. The education objective of this CAREER program is to create decision models for use in outreach, educational, and management activities; in return, interactions with stakeholders, students, and teachers will provide feedback for designing cutting-edge and practical mathematical models.

The research efforts will include: (1) design of a novel decomposition-based optimization framework that will help to overcome a big challenge of computational complexity in spatio-temporal optimization; (2) development of rigorous optimization models and methods to solve high-dimensional resource allocation problems in environmental management; (3) development of a decision support tool to provide efficient management practices for invasive species management, in collaboration with ecologists, managers, and policy makers; (4) advancements in theory and methodology through a rigorous analysis of uncertainty and novel surveillance and control modeling; (5) a new class of game theoretic models and algorithms that can be used to provide fundamental insights into the design of public policies for environmental management; and (6) modeling, algorithmic, and computational advances in discrete optimization, which potentially may help solve other important optimization problems.

This award is co-funded by the CBET/ENG Environmental Sustainability program and the DMS/MPS Division under BioMaPs.

por.por_cntn:
This research program has provided new mathematical modeling and logistics optimization techniques and tools to tackle invasive species that create havoc on forests and agriculture. The research team has focused explicitly on the emerald ash borer (EAB) killing ash trees in North America and Canada and Sericea Lespedeza damaging agricultural products in the Great Plains of the U.S. The research results, models, and methodologies from this work have helped policymakers in natural resources, ecology, and forestry optimize the location and timing of resource allocation under limited budgets.

The insights gained from our research results regarding the optimal surveillance and control planning of the EAB address two quandaries facing managers: whether to invest in surveillance and to treat healthy-looking ash trees. Our results imply that surveillance and treatment of ash trees are more beneficial than removing trees over many cost and infestation scenarios, addressing a long-lasting debate among foresters. Managers use the insights from our mathematical models to inform their surveillance and control strategies.

The analysis of our game theoretical incentive models shows that the optimal reimbursement depends not only on the initial infestation level but also on the treatment effectiveness and the likelihood of new infestations. When treatment is likely to be very effective (i.e., when trees are either healthy or have less than 50 percent canopy decline), treating all trees is optimal regardless of the number of trees infested. In this case, the reimbursement required to induce the landowner to treat all trees is likely to be small. When the treatment is not likely to be very effective (i.e., when infested trees have greater than 50 percent canopy damage) and the number of infested trees in the first period is high, not treating any trees and removing them after 1-3 years is optimal.  Through extensive numerical analysis, we conclude that the treatment-based reimbursement policy induces the landowner to treat more trees through a higher reimbursement and provides a higher overall benefit to the forester when compared to the infestation-based reimbursement policy. Our approach may inspire other private-public partnerships to solve various environmental and societal problems through better resource sharing, such as the management of water, land, and wildfire.

Our main findings regarding the surveillance and control of sericea in the Great Plains of the U.S. indicate that the optimal treatment strategies are quite sensitive to the input data, such as the landscape size and the planning horizon, and depend on several factors, such as the budget, the germination rate, and dispersal rates. Thus, it is difficult to find intuitive strategies without using a complex mathematical model such as the one we developed in this NSF CAREER program, implying the need to utilize a simulation-optimization mathematical modeling framework case-by-case to capture the most effective management strategies to fight against the invasion of sericea.

Integrated research and educational activities have bridged theory and practice by involving researchers, scientists, and practitioners in modeling efforts. Specifically, this research program has cultivated synergy among academics and professionals in operations research (OR) and Environmental Sustainability by publishing papers in domain journals in both societies, giving talks at leading industrial engineering, operations research, and forestry conferences, and collaborating with researchers from biology, entomology, forestry, and environmental sustainability areas. This career program has also involved nine doctoral students (two of them are female), two female postdoctoral research associates, four undergraduate students (three of them are female), and two female academicians.
